elements.name: qualifyIntroText
elements.title:
Represent Someone Who Died (also known as Probate)

Use this service to apply for a `Representation Grant` from the Supreme Court of British Columbia. A Representation Grant is a court document that confirms you are the appropriate person to manage the property, money and other belongings that a person left behind after they died. The collection of `assets` that a person left behind is called their `estate`

Representation Grant is an umbrella term that includes different types of these court documents. A Grant of Probate is a type of Representation Grant specifically for executors named in a `Will`.

Court Costs and Fees
There is no cost to use this service and the service will create the documents you need to file with the Court. There will be costs associated when filing which are:
  • There will either be a $200 filing fee or a $0 filing fee (if the estate is worth less than $25,000).
  • There will be costs for swearing or affirming the `affidavits` that this service will create for you. Each affidavit costs $40 to swear or affirm at a courthouse. An application usually has 3 or more affidavits.
  • There will be probate fees if the estate is worth more than $25,000. This fee will be a small percentage of the total value.

elements.name: qualifyingIntroExplanation
elements.title:
A Representation Grant costs money and will take time to get. Don't waste time on this service if you don't need one.

For example, if the `deceased` had money in their bank account, that bank may give you that money to manage without a Representation Grant.

Different organizations have different policies to make sure that the right person gets the deceased's `assets`.

Ask each of the organizations that deal with the deceased's assets if they will give you the asset without a Representation Grant (also known as a Grant of `Probate`). If an organization will not give you an asset, they will likely ask you to get a Representation Grant.

In addition, ask each of organizations that provided services to the deceased, (such as an electric company, phone company, credit card company, etc) if they will let you cancel the service without a Representation Grant.

elements.name: needGrant
elements.title: Were you asked by an organization to get a Representation Grant (or a Grant of `Probate`)?
elements.description: This question is asking about organizations that hold the deceased's assets or provided a serviced to the deceased.

elements.name: needGrantNoExplanation
elements.title: If all of the organizations that hold the deceased's assets simply gave you those assets to manage, then you probably don't need Representation Grant.

elements.name: stillNeedGrant
elements.title: Do you still want to use this service to apply for a Representation Grant?

elements.name: stillNeedGrantNoError
elements.title:
It seems you don't need this service to manage the deceased's assets.

The organizations that hold the the deceased's assets may ask you to sign a waiver in case there are problems in the future.

Once you have the assets, you are responsible for distributing them according to the law.

If the deceased made a Will, do your best to follow instruction in the Will on how to distribute the assets.

If the deceased did not make a Will, there are rules written in the Wills, Estates and Succession Act (WESA Part 3 Division 1) on how to distribute the assets. There are different rules depending on the deceased's family situation.

Read the rules written in WESA (Part 3 Division 1) here. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: qualifyingTempScopeExplanation
elements.title:
As of June 21, 2022, this service has only been developed for the first step in applying for a Representation Grant.

This service will:
  • Help an `applicant` create a Form P1 and send it to whoever is required to receive one.
  • Help the applicant create a Form P9 that lists the people they gave a Form P1.

This service has only been developed for situations where:
  • Only a single person is applying for the Representation Grant.
  • You are one of the following:
    • a `spouse` of the deceased,
    • a child of the deceased,
    • someone who the deceased owed more than $10,000, or
    • you can also be a `legal guardian`, `nominee` or `personal representative` for someone listed above.
  • Even if you are one of the people listed above, this service can NOT help you if one of the deceasedâ€™s children has died before them and that child has children of their own.

Note: If there is no surviving spouse, descendant or creditor identified, other than yourself, at this time, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant. For more information on who may need to be notified, refer to Supreme Court Civil Rule 25-2(2)

elements.name: qualifyingTempScope
elements.title: Does the above situation match your situation?

elements.name: qualifyingTempScopeNoError
elements.title:
If the above conditions don't match your situation, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant at this point in time.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations.

Please check later to see if this service has been developed for your specific situation. This service is continuously expanding to help more and more people.

In the mean time, the Government of British Columbia offers PDF forms that you may find helpful for your application. Click here to go to the forms. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: indianActExplanation
elements.title:
This service needs to know if the deceased was either a Registered Indian or entitled to be Registered under the Government of Canada's Indian Act when they died.

For more information about who is considered a Registered Indian or entitled to be a Registered Indian, click here to go to the Government of Canada's Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The name of the Indian Act and its policies are not under the control of the Government of British Columbia.

elements.name: registeredIndian
elements.title: Was the deceased a Registered Indian under the Government of Canada's Indian Act when they died?
elements.description: If the deceased was a Nisga'a citizen or a member of a Treaty First Nation in British Columbia, select "NO." This service will have more questions about this situation in a later step.

elements.name: registeredIndianEntitled
elements.title: Was the deceased entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act when they died?
elements.description:
If the deceased was a Nisga'a citizen or a member of a Treaty First Nation in British Columbia, select "NO." This service will have more questions about this situation in a later step.

The deceased was entitled to be registered if at least one of the their parents is registered or entitled to be registered under section 6 of the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

If anyone in the deceasedâ€™s immediate or extended family registered or was entitled to be registered, it may mean the deceased was entitled to register as well. If you are unsure, Indigenous Services Canada estate officers can help you. They can't give you legal advice. Call:
604-775-5100 (Greater Vancouver)
1-888-917-9977 (elsewhere in BC)

elements.name: registeredIndianReferredToBC
elements.title: Have you contacted an estate officer at Indigenous Services Canada (ISC) and were told to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a Representation Grant for the deceased?

elements.name: registeredIndianYesExplanation
elements.title:
If the deceased was a Registered Indian and Indigenous Services Canada (ISC) did NOT tell you to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a Representation Grant, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant.

According to the Government of Canada's Indian Act, Indigenous Services Canada (ISC) is in charge of choosing who will manage the property of a Registered Indian who has died.

An Estate Officer at Indigenous Services Canada can assist you with this. For more information, click here to access Indigenous Relations Canada. (This link opens in a new tab)

For more information, click here to read Sections 42 to 45 about Descent of Property in the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The Indian Act is federal legislation. The Government of Canada is separate and independent from the Government of British Columbia. All inquiries about the Indian Act should be directed to the Government of Canada.

elements.name: registeredIndianEntitledNoExplanation
elements.title:
If the deceased was entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act and Indigenous Services Canada (ISC) did NOT tell you to go to the Supreme Court of British Columbia to get a Representation Grant, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant.

According to the Government of Canada's Indian Act, Indigenous Services Canada (ISC) is in charge of choosing who will manage the property of someone who was entitled to register under the Government of Canada's Indian Act. An Estate Officer at Indigenous Services Canada can assist you with this. For more information, click here to access Indigenous Relations Canada. (This link opens in a new tab)

For more information, click here to read Sections 42 to 45 about Descent of Property in the Indian Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

Please Note: The Indian Act is federal legislation. The Government of Canada is separate and independent from the Government of British Columbia. All inquiries about the Indian Act should be directed to the Government of Canada.

elements.name: qualifyingAfterWESAPanel
qualifyingDiedAfterWESA
elements.title: Did the deceased die after March 30, 2014?

elements.name: qualifyingDiedAfterWESANoError
elements.title:
At this point in time, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant if the deceased died on March 30, 2014, or before.

The Wills, Estate and Succession Act became law on March 31, 2014. This service only supports the current laws.

If the deceased died before the current Wills, Estate and Succession Act came into effect, your application also needs to comply with the old Estate Administration Act.

Please review both sets of laws to make sure your application will be successful.
  • the Estate Administration Act (This link opens in a new tab)
  • the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: qualifyingTermsPanel
qualifyingTerms
elements.title:
This service can help you apply for a Representation Grant. Before continuing, please read the terms for using this service.

'Represent Someone Who Died' is a service provided by the Government of British Columbia.

  • The Supreme Court of British Columbia will review the documents that you create through this service.
  • The Court may ask you for additional information even if you have used this service.
  • The Court will decide whether or not to give you a Representation Grant.
The Government of British Columbia may update this service at any time.

  • Learn more about the disclaimer and liability here. (This link opens in a new tab)
  • Learn more about privacy and security here. (This link opens in a new tab)
By clicking "Continue", you are agreeing to these terms.
